columns.text:
a. The strategy of holding the asset and a put option to avoid the downside risk is called a protective put.

A protective put can also act as an insurance policy that provides safety against losses when the corresponding asset declines in value.

Protective put using a hypothetical situation.

Assume Investor A owns an asset that has a current value of $S_o$. Also, assume that the asset makes no cash payments and has no carrying cost.

Assume the holding period as time $T$, at which point the asset will be worth $S_T$.

If at $T$, the value of the asset declines that is, falls short of $S_o$, an investor can hedge against this situation by buying a put option which has a  strike price of $x$ and a premium of $p_o$.

Therefore, the investor's current position is worth $S_o+p_o$, which is the investor's money at risk.

After the holding period that is, $T$, the value of the asset is $S_T$.

If the asset increases in value that is, the value of the asset price in the market is greater than the strike price of the option that is, $x$ or $S_T\geq x$, when the investor will let the option expire.

If the asset value declines in value that are, $S_T < x$, at this point in time investor will take the advantage of the put option and sell the asset at $x$.

Therefore, by using a protective put strategy, an investor gets the benefit of unlimited upside potential, while the downside performs once limited to $x$.

b. A strategy that exactly duplicates a protective put is "fiduciary call".

Continuing with the above example and using some of the above facts.
Consider another Investor who buys a call option on an asset that has a worth now as $S_o$. Assume the option expires at time $T$, at which point of time the asset is worth $S_T$ and the corresponding call option has a strike price of $x$.

If at time $T$, the market price of the asset is less than $S_T$ or the strike price of the option that is, $S_T\leq x$. In this case, the investor will let the option expire and purchases the asset in the market.

In other words, if the asset is worth more than the strike price of the option in the market that is, $S_T > x$. In this case, the investor will exercise the option and purchase the asset at $x$.
